entities.summary: Research and Innovation STRATEGIC PLAN 2025 - 2027 Horizon Europe strategic plan (2025 – 2027) European Commission Directorate-General for Research and Innovation Directorate G — Policy & Programming Centre Unit G.3.

entities.name: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan 2025-2027
entities.summary: Investment in R&I is directed towards tackling key global challenges. These include climate change, pollution, loss of biodiversity and the digital transition. The document provides a certain degree of flexibility to respond to unforeseen challenges.

entities.name: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan | 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: Horizon Europe has been generating excellence through breakthrough knowledge and investment in solutions to long-term global challenges. Challenges include climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, the digital transformation, health threats and an ageing population. These challenges have been exacerbated by an unstable geopolitical context.

entities.name: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan | 2025 – 2027 The following key strategic orientations outline the main priorities for 2025-2027.
entities.summary: Horizon Europe has an explicit and ambitious commitment to spend at least 35% of its funding resources on climate action. In 2021-2027, it is agreed to invest at least EUR 13 billion from Horizon Europe in core digital technologies. Europe’s social rights and democratic values and principles

entities.name: 1. Open strategic autonomy 2. Open strategic autonomy 3. Open strategic autonomy 4. Open strategic autonomy 5. Open strategic autonomy 6.
entities.summary: 'Open strategic autonomy' refers to the term ‘strategic autonomy, while preserving an open economy’ It is further set out in the Communication from the Commission Trade Policy Review, COM(2021) 66.

entities.name: EU health industry Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture & Environment Climate, Energy & Mobility Digital, Industry & Space Civil Security for Society Culture, Creativity & Inclusive Society Health Green Transition Digital Transition A more Resilient, Competitive, Inclusive, & Democratic Europe
entities.summary: What is the role of EU health industry in this policy context? Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture & Environment Climate, Energy & Mobility Digital, Industry & Space Civil Security for Society Culture, Creativity & Inclusive Society Health Green Transition Digital Transition.

entities.name: European Commission, Horizon Europe, 2025-2027
entities.summary: European Commission, Horizon Europe, 2025-2027 in this policy context. It strives to ensure the best value and impact for Member States and Associated Countries’ investment in R&I. It supports the below aspects: Continuity and reliability for the R &I communities.

entities.name: European Economic Security Strategy
entities.summary: The European Economic Security Strategy was set up in line with the monitoring and evaluation provisions of the Horizon Europe Regulation14. The Commission has:simplified the impact logic by removing the ‘impact areas’ to reduce complexity and focus on the expected impacts.

entities.name: EU strategy for 2025-2027
entities.summary: EU strategy for 2025-2027 in this policy context. Council Decision (EU) 2021/764 of 10 May 2021 establishing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation.

entities.name: Horizon Europe
entities.summary: Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine and the situation in the Middle East highlight the need for open strategic autonomy. All six clusters under Pillar II of Horizon Europe will support each of the three key strategic orientations, in order to maximise integration and synergies.

entities.name: EU Missions
entities.summary: The EU will need to make improvements in several areas to address ongoing and future climate threats. These improvements will also require: (i) behavioural and structural change at societal level; (ii) transformational decision-making; and (iii) social acceptance.

entities.name: EU strategy for 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: The European way to a digitalised economy and society is about combining solidarity, prosperity and sustainability, anchored in empowerment of its people and businesses. Horizon Europe plays a crucial role in shaping and developing the key technologies for the digital transformation the European way.

entities.name: EU strategy for Europe
entities.summary: Cluster 1 aims to promote health equity and ensure fair and equal access to innovative, sustainable, high-quality healthcare for everyone. Cluster 2 aims to make Europe more resilient, competitive, inclusive and democratic.

entities.name: EU strategy for green and digital transitions
entities.summary: Cluster 4 will help create a globally competitive European digital sector. The success of this strategy will allow Europe to stand out as an innovation leader. Embracing digitalisation, also in space, will revolutionise satellite design.

entities.name: EU strategy plan | 2025 – 2027 Cluster 5 – Climate, Energy and Mobility Cluster 5 – Climate, Energy and Mobility Cluster 6 – Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment
entities.summary: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan | 2025 – 2027 Cluster 5 – Climate, Energy and Mobility. Cluster 6 – Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment drives forward the green transition.

entities.name: European Union
entities.summary: The European Union is moving ahead with its goals to: (i) achieve climate neutrality by 2050; (ii) reduce net greenhouse-gas emissions by 55% by 2030; (iii) shift to a circular economy; and (iv) protect biodiversity. The New European Bauhaus

entities.name: EU Research Area
entities.summary: The NEB will be implemented as a cross-cluster issue in the Horizon Europe work programmes for 2025-2027. It will also bolster democratic values and inclusion through the involvement of communities in the design of public spaces and common goods.

entities.name: European Research Infrastructures
entities.summary: Research infrastructures (RI) empower researchers in Europe by supporting and optimising an integrated ecosystem of sustainable, world-class and accessible national and pan- European research infrastructure. The actions equip excellent researchers in all research areas with new knowledge and skills as well as with international

entities.name: European Institute of Innovation and Technology
entities.summary: The EIC will focus on deep-tech innovations in line with the priorities of the New European Innovation Agenda, while also supporting other types of innovation, including social innovation. The results of EIC-funded initiatives will contribute to the objectives of Pillar II and feed into the evidence base for

entities.name: European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT)
entities.summary: The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) will launch in 2026 a new KIC Water, Marine and Maritime Sectors and Ecosystems. EIT will continue to provide support to Pillar II of Horizon Europe, particularly to address innovation at systemic level.

entities.name: European Research Area Policy Agenda
entities.summary: Widening Participation and Strengthening the European Research Area part (WIDERA) supports the priorities set out in the Pact for Research and Innovation in Europe. The EIE will strengthen cooperation with other EU initiatives that focus on innovation such as Startup Europe.

entities.name: EU Policy Agenda, Horizon Europe, Horizon 2020, Horizon Europe, Horizon Europe
entities.summary: Technology Infrastructures bridge the gap between science and innovation supporting industrial capacity building. New activities will be tested under the Horizon Europe pillars implementing the 2022-2024 ERA Policy Agenda.

entities.name: EU strategy for international cooperation
entities.summary: The EU's approach to international cooperation will continue to focus on openness of Horizon Europe and multilateralism, combined with strategic targeted actions with key partners from outside the EU.

entities.name: EU-India Trade and Technology Council)
entities.summary: Association to the framework programme41 is the strongest form of international cooperation. It is also an efficient way to bring additional funding to the Horizon Europe programme. The association of some of the EU’s key global allies will strengthen alliances.

entities.name: EU action on R&I foreign interference
entities.summary: The toolkit on tackling foreign R&I interference43 aims at helping to raise awareness and build resilience in the R &I sector across Europe. The Code of Practice on the management of intellectual assets for knowledge valorisation44 is a very useful guide for R and I cooperation.

entities.name: Horizon Europe strategy plan | 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: Key enabling technologies of the future include advanced materials and nanotechnology; photonics and micro- and nano-electronics; life- science technologies; advanced manufacturing and processing; AI; digital security; and connectivity. KETs also have the potential to foster future jobs for Europeans.

entities.name: EU policy areas
entities.summary: Horizon Europe provides a wide range of guidance, tools and opportunities to incentivise beneficiaries and provide them with practical support. The dissemination and exploitation of the results of EU-funded projects feed into EU policy-making.

entities.name: EU strategy plan 2025 – 2027 OPEN SCIENCE PRACTICE Horizon Europe will continue to support and mainstream open science as the gold standard for R&I activities. This method involves openly sharing knowledge, data and tools as early as possible with all relevant knowledge actors and society. The aim is to increase the quality and impact of R&I, support the dissemination of knowledge and improve responsiveness to global challenges. The Horizon Europe Regulation makes key open science practices mandatory, namely open access to scientific publications, and implementing responsible management of research data in line with the FAIR principles of ‘findability’, ‘accessibility’, ‘interoperability’ and ‘reusability’, notably through the obligations
entities.summary: Horizon Europe will continue to support and mainstream open science as the gold standard for R&I activities. This method involves openly sharing knowledge, data and tools as early as possible with all relevant knowledge actors and society. The aim is to increase the quality and impact of R &I, support

entities.name: European Court of Auditors’ Special Report No 23/2022 ‘Synergies between Horizon 2020 and European Structural and Investment Funds’
entities.summary: The success of Horizon Europe will be enhanced through synergies with other EU funding programmes. These include demonstration and piloting capacities, specific deployment programmes, transfer and sharing of knowledge and data.

entities.name: EU strategy | 2025 – 2027 - downstream synergy aiming to enhance the take-up of Horizon Europe and other research results towards the market and concrete deployment.
entities.summary: EU strategy aims to enhance the take-up of Horizon Europe and other research results towards the market and concrete deployment. The EU’s centrally managed programmes, like Horizon Europe, play a mobilising role for new ideas and approaches.

entities.name: EU policy themes, programmes, clusters, and impact areas
entities.summary: Horizon Europe63 commits to dedicating at least 35% of its total budget to climate objectives. The latest estimates based on monitoring data for 2021-2022 indicate that for 2021/2022 35% is dedicated to climate. For 2023-24, based on ex

entities.name: Research and innovation
entities.summary: Key to delivering on this expected impact is the availability and accessibility of real-world health data. R&I activities will contribute to the European care strategy70 and the digital transformation of health and care in the EU71.

entities.name: European health policy
entities.summary: Healthcare providers will improve their ability to tackle and manage diseases. This will reduce the disease burden on patients and enable healthcare systems to perform more effectively. International cooperation is indispensable to rapidly advance research and innovation.

entities.name: Developing and using new tools, technologies, and digital solutions for a healthy society
entities.summary: Developing and using new tools, technologies, and digital solutions for a healthy society in this policy context. Research and innovation can help deliver solutions that are scalable and transferable between different types of healthcare systems.

entities.name: EU health sector
entities.summary: The expected impact is that the EU health industry is innovative, sustainable, and globally competitive thanks to improved uptake of breakthrough technologies and innovations. There is a need to further support cross-sectoral R&I and the convergence of health technologies to strengthen the single market.

entities.name: EU Global Health Strategy
entities.summary: The EU has established solid links with non-EU countries and international organisations. With the EU Global Health Strategy, the EU seeks to regain lost ground. Europe’s Health Cluster will remain an essential vehicle for executing EU commitments.

entities.name: HORIZON EUROPE strategy plan 2025-2027 Synergies with other EU funding programmes
entities.summary: A dedicated Horizon Europe partnership on One Health antimicrobial resistance. Preparedness and quick response to public health emergencies. Personalised medicine. Impact of the environment on human health.

entities.name: EU4Health
entities.summary: Horizon Europe funding in recent years was devoted to research on pathogens with high pandemic potential. EU4Health actions are helping to speed up the development of and access to medical countermeasures for epidemic and pandemic preparedness. Sequential synergies will also be developed between Cluster 1 and

entities.name: EU strategy plan 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: EU strategy plan 2025 – 2027 in policy context. What is the role of EU strategy plan in this policy context?

entities.name: Cluster 2 will programme investment to achieve the following four expected impacts.
entities.summary: Cluster 2 will programme investment to achieve the following four expected impacts. in this policy context. Investments will help foster more resilient European democracies.

entities.name: Reinvigorating democratic governance
entities.summary: Reinvigorating democratic governance aims to bolster the resilience of democratic systems and protect them from threats. R&I actions will aim to increase the capacity of researchers and policy makers to better understand geopolitical shifts and shape the EU’s role in the world.

entities.name: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan | 2025 – 2027 priorities: green, digital and innovative
entities.summary: HORIZON EUROPE strategic plan | 2025 – 2027 priorities: green, digital and innovative in this policy context. Realising the full potential of cultural heritage, arts and cultural and creative sectors.

entities.name: Strengthening social and economic resilience and sustainability
entities.summary: This is expected to help improve collaboration between European cultural heritage institutions and networks. It will support high-quality acquisition, management and curation of digitised and born digital heritage assets. Research may further explore sustainable and inclusive cultural tourism.

entities.name: EU strategy plan | 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: The implications of these ongoing changes are far-reaching, affecting various aspects of society and the economy. To address these changes effectively, it is vital to not only understand existing and emerging inequalities, but also to prioritise social justice.

entities.name: Synergies with other EU funding programmes
entities.summary: The Horizon Europe cluster on Culture, Creativity and Inclusive Society will aim at promoting synergies with other EU programmes. This may include strategic areas of mutual benefit in the context of the new EU-Latin America and the Caribbean initiative.

entities.name: Synergies with EU programmes
entities.summary: Sequential synergies could then be encouraged at a further stage, following the ESF+ implementation on the ground. With EU programmes such as Erasmus+, European Solidarity Corps and DiscoverEU, there is potential for fostering synergies. There is also potential for synergies with EU

entities.name: EU strategy for 2025 – 2027 CIVIL SECURITY C
entities.summary: EU strategy for 2025 – 2027 CIVIL SECURITY C in this policy context. Research on the nature of job transformations for industry 4.0/5.0 and its role in transitioning to a sustainable, human-centric and resilient Europe.

entities.name: EU security
entities.summary: The EU needs to be prepared to face the increasing threat from terrorism and organised crime. The more wide- spread and ubiquitous digital technology is, the greater cyber threats may become, putting infrastructures, businesses and individuals at risk. Cybersecurity is key for all areas of the economy

entities.name: EU Security Union Strategy
entities.summary: Cluster 3 will continue to support the implementation of the                 EU Security Union Strategy and the sectoral strategies. The following horizontal priorities will be developed through work programme actions.

entities.name: EU security research
entities.summary: In line with the EU Charter of                 Fundamental Rights and the Commission’s ‘Union of Equality’ priorities, the diversity and gender balance of members of the public involved in security research will be ensured. Cluster 3 will programme investment to achieve the four expected

entities.name: Actions for crisis management
entities.summary: Actions will continue to explore initiatives and experiments involving the development of technological or methodological solutions for crisis management and support for emergency responders. The EU should learn from past disasters by identifying gaps in capabilities.

entities.name: EU strategy, programmes, clusters, or impact areas
entities.summary: Cluster 3 should focus on its ‘core added value’, which is a strong operational character for preparedness, response and learning. There are similar examples of closer coordination with Cluster 6 and the One Health approach, regarding threats to water and food security.

entities.name: EU strategy, EU Arctic policy, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0, EU Drone Strategy 2.0
entities.summary: Emerging challenges may include threats of illicit flows of dangerous materials (explosives, radiological materials) and weapons across the EU’s eastern borders. The EU will design increasing integration within this destination across the thematic areas and users’ communities.

entities.name: Investment
entities.summary: Investment provides further support for modern information analysis, modern forensics tools and the recognition of societal problems arising from various forms of crime. The destination will continue to pay close attention to financial crimes, as a  common denominator for most criminal activities.

entities.name: Actions to strengthen the resilience of critical infrastructure
entities.summary: Both the physical and digital aspects of critical infrastructure need to be considered. The resilience of supply chains in general and maritime ports in particular needs to be improved. The EU will develop capabilities to ensure that inclusive smart cities are resilient, secure and protected.

entities.name: EU Cybersecurity Strategy
entities.summary: The approach is designed to provide open, free, stable and secure cyberspace, secure hardware and software systems and a digital environment. The operational risk management assessment cycle will be improved to include cybersecurity risks.

entities.name: EU policy
entities.summary: The destination will generate greater knowledge of standards or breakthrough research in all the thematic areas. It will promote innovation uptake, by using innovation procurement for example. The Commission will continue to develop the following supporting measures76:Embedding security research in a forward-looking and needs-driven

entities.name: EU strategy for European Research and Innovation for Security (CERIS)
entities.summary: Community for European Research and Innovation for Security (CERIS) Harnessing potential of standardisation as a catalyst for market uptake in civil security. Continuing to operationalise the synergies-by-design between EU civil security research and other EU funds.

entities.name: EU strategy for research and innovation
entities.summary: The EU is committed to preserve openness in international research and innovation cooperation. Targeted cooperation with Africa will be considered for topics of importance for Africa. Cluster 3 will continue building and facilitating synergies with other EU funding programmes.

entities.name: EU strategy
entities.summary: The EU has the potential to become a leading player in the net-zero industries of the future, but further investment is needed. Resilience and technological sovereignty have become renewed priorities for the EU due to the current geopolitical and economic context.

entities.name: Cluster 4 will programme investment to achieve the six following expected impacts.
entities.summary: Cluster 4 aims at decisive progress and an internationally leading position for Europe in the key digital and space technologies. These technologies include AI, advanced computing, photonics, microelectronics, industrial internet-of-things and next generation internet.

entities.name: Achieving global leadership in climate-neutral, circular and digitised industrial and digital value chains
entities.summary: Achieving global leadership in climate-neutral, circular and digitised industrial and digital value chains. Supporting net-zero manufacturing is a key objective of the Net-Zero industry Act84. Breakthrough technologies to be exploited beyond 2030 will also play an important role.

entities.name: Process industries
entities.summary: The EU has set an ambitious goal for Europe to become the first climate-neutral continent by 2050. Reducing emissions in industrial sectors will require coordinated action throughout value chains. Hubs4Circularity is a tool that allows for place-based innovation, whenever possible in conjunction with existing concepts

entities.name: European Digital Innovation Hubs
entities.summary: Hubs4Circularity should deal not only with first-of-a-kind demonstrators, but also with theformation of existing plants. It will require that the place-based development of recycling technologies and materials research also benefits energy-intensive industries and cities.

entities.name: European Chips Act
entities.summary: Digital twins, cyber-physical systems, internet of things and virtual worlds will help all people benefit from the power of data and AI in a fair, unbiased and compliant way. Quantum technologies will further expand the data economy in high value-added areas where traditional approaches struggle to deliver.

entities.name: Achieving open strategic autonomy in global space-based infrastructures, services, applications and data
entities.summary: Europe’s strength in quantum technologies is a strategic asset for its future security and independence. Space is a sector that helps to ensure that the EU is not dependent on other parts of the globe when security and/or political independence come into play.

entities.name: EU Horizon Europe
entities.summary: EU Horizon Europe will emphasise multilateral cooperation in areas of common interest. Collaborative R&I will be complemented by industrial and policy discussions to achieve these aims.

entities.name: European Commission: Global Approach to Research and Innovation
entities.summary: The EU will step up its cooperation with its closest partners on the development of integrated production and services networks. The cluster will ensure the safeguarding of the EU’s strategic assets, interests, autonomy, and security in critical areas.

entities.name: Synergies with the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF)
entities.summary: ‘Destination Earth’ will greatly benefit from integrating cutting-edge results from the cluster. The Digital Europe Programme is also relevant for space-related activities, especially when it comes to Copernicus.

entities.name: climate, energy, and mobility
entities.summary: LIFE’s subprogrammes (notably Climate Change Mitigation and Adaptation) have  several projects in industry for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and air pollutants. What is the role of climate, energy, and mobility in this policy context?

entities.name: climate change
entities.summary: The European Climate Law, European Green Deal, Fit for 55 package, and Net-Zero Industry Act are just a few of the initiatives Cluster 5 will be involved in. The Cluster will also contribute to the Commission’s A Europe fit for the digital age and An economy that

entities.name: EU Research Area on climate change
entities.summary: Artificial intelligence solutions can be used to accelerate research in these crucial topics. What is the role of EU Research Area on climate change in this policy context?

entities.name: EU Missions ‘climate- neutral and smart cities’ and ‘adaptation to climate change’
entities.summary: EU Missions ‘climate- neutral and smart cities’ and ‘adaptation to climate change’ will complement these actions. R&I actions will support the just energy transition through new solutions for smart energy systems based on renewable energy.

entities.name: Using energy in buildings and industry in an efficient, affordable and sustainable way
entities.summary: Using energy in buildings and industry in an efficient, affordable and sustainable way. Buildings responsible for around 50% of EU energy demand when considering their full life cycle.

entities.name: Transport
entities.summary: Transport is the only sector where greenhouse gas emissions have increased. The transport sector is responsible for 23% of CO2 emissions in the EU. Electrification of all modes of transport plays a key role in this process.

entities.name: European Partnerships for Transport
entities.summary: R&I initiatives are needed to prepare the transformation of supply-based transport to demand-driven, multimodal, safe, secure, climate-neutral, and sustainable mobility. R&I will support the development of emerging digital technologies, vehicle-to-infrastructure/ vehicle-

entities.name: EU Research and Innovation Partnership on Climate Change and Sustainable Energy
entities.summary: The EU plans to develop further the AU-EU Research and Innovation Partnership on Climate Change and Sustainable Energy. The EU will strengthen international cooperation in several other areas of transport research.

entities.name: 1. HEALTH 2. HEALTH & health-active mobility 3. Health & safety in transport and buildings.
entities.summary: The European Green Deal, REPowerEU and the zero-pollution policy framework aim at  facilitating the deployment of innovative solutions. Existing complementarities between the programmes will be strengthened, for example by reducing market barriers.

entities.name: EU Green Deal
entities.summary: Empowering citizens to engage in the transformation to a climate-neutral and resilient society. What is the role of EU Green Deal in this policy context?

entities.name: EU action plan on protecting and restoring marine ecosystems for sustainable and resilient fisheries
entities.summary: Cluster 6 supports the ambition of Europe to become the first climate-neutral and climate-resilient continent by 2050. The development of sustainable agriculture and food systems is one of the key priority areas of action for the EU. The implementation of unifying approaches through R&I is

entities.name: EU action plan | 2025 – 2027
entities.summary: Cluster 6 is expected to substantially contribute to achieving the target of dedicating 10% of the Horizon Europe budget to biodiversity and ecosystems objectives. The acceleration of global crises calls for accelerating the transition towards a sustainable, climate-neutral, clean and competitive economy.

entities.name: EU Missions ‘A Soil Deal for Europe’ and ‘Restore our Ocean and Waters’
entities.summary: Cluster 6 supports the revised Regulation on land use, land use change and forestry. It also supports the proposal for an EU regulation on the certification of carbon removals.

entities.name: EU biodiversity strategy for 2030
entities.summary: The protection and restoration of ecosystems, habitats and species will require new and better knowledge and methods, duly tested, and monitored at appropriate scales. This includes needs identified in the communication 'A New Deal for Pollinators', COM(2023) 35, 24.1.2023.

entities.name: EU Action Plan for the Future
entities.summary: R&I will support the development of innovative circular, bioeconomy and nature-based solutions. It will foster social and technological innovation within planetary boundaries.

entities.name: EU strategy for rural development
entities.summary: R&I will help transform food systems by making them more innovative, inclusive, anddigitally driven. Fish and seafood production will rely on low-impact fishing and aquatic ecosystems and resources, while monitoring tools will be essential to ensure their sustainability.

entities.name: EU Rural and Coastal Resilience and Sustainability Cluster 6
entities.summary: The options of sustainable farming approaches, including organic farming and aquaculture as well as agroecology, in providing economic opportunities in rural areas will be explored. Initiatives will be rolled out to support citizen science, literacy, and observation and stewardship of rivers, freshwater, and

entities.name: EU Biodiversity Framework
entities.summary: European Biodiversity Framework (Biodiversa+) is designed to support the 4 and 23 goals and targets for 2030 set in the Kunming-Montreal Biodiversity Framework (COP-15) R&I activities in Cluster 6 will be designed around the

entities.name: EU-Africa Global Gateway Investment Package
entities.summary: Cluster 6 will also support international action to stop and remove pollution. It is part of the EU-Africa Global Gateway Investment Package | 2025 – 2027.
